reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: Support the creation, improvement and sustainability of physical infrastructure, and related services, in both urban and rural areas, to enhance the economic environment and improve economic productivity, including for women. The main infrastructures include energy, including electric power transmission lines and distribution networks, oil/gas terminals, refineries, storage facilities and pipelines; telecom and ICT; and transport, including roads, airports, railways, and ports.

This award supports the creation, improvement and sustainability of physical infrastructure, and related services, in both urban and rural areas, to enhance the economic environment and improve economic productivity, including for women,. More specifically, this award includes a A USTDA grant to the Ministry of Energy of the Government of Sierra Leone ('Grantee') will fund a feasibility study ('Study') to evaluate the technical, economic, and commercial viability of providing approximately five minigrids for commercial and industrial users (e.g., factories and commercial farms, telecom towers, universities, government buildings) and surrounding communities and approximately 40 minigrids for villages (the 'Project'). These minigrids will potentially provide energy access to over 8,600 people, promoting a higher quality of life and economic development. The Study will also create an opportunity for U.S. companies to provide goods, services, and expertise. The Grantee has selected WindGen Power USA, Inc. of Delray Beach, Florida to perform the Study and help implement the Project.. A USTDA grant to the Ministry of Energy of the Government of Sierra Leone will fund a feasibility study to evaluate the technical, economic, and commercial viability of providing approximately five minigrids for commercial and industrial users (e.g., factories and commercial farms, telecom towers, universities, government buildings) and surrounding communities and approximately 40 minigrids for villages . These minigrids will potentially provide energy access to over 8,600 people, promoting a higher quality of life and economic development..

participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: Despite experiencing the most severe Ebola Virus disease outbreak ever recorded, Sierra Leone has made significant gains in consolidating peace, promoting democracy at local and national levels, encouraging economic growth and facilitating overall engagement in development processes. Nevertheless, Sierra Leone continues to grapple with serious development challenges, such as entrenched corruption, weak governmental institutions, high unemployment, slow economic growth and inadequate social services, including water and electricity. U.S. assistance will improve the daily lives of Sierra Leoneans through strategic investments in agriculture and health services, including farmer training, nutrition programs and policy reform. U.S. assistance will also target civil society and media programming, security sector reform, and rule of law programs. The U.S. government will accomplish these goals through close collaboration with the Government of Sierra Leone (GOSL), other donors, local non-governmental organizations, and the private sector.
